body:
This pr aims to add multiline support to the prompt buffer. 

Works toward #32420 and #32661

### Proposal:
- Track how much text has been submitted already to the prompt buffer callback.
- When the user submits, send the text after the previously submitted point.
- Make the content before last submit Readonly so it's locked in place.

### Questions:
- ~~How to handle buffer changes through API ?~~ Keep track of the location through marks so edits don't effect the position.
- ~~The callback may insert or remove text in the buffer before we lock in the submit location?~~ same as above
- Should we expose this location to user somehow?

### Example:
 
https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/5b45027d-328c-46f3-a70d-6342d3fa6d84


### Notes
- [x] Figure out how submition key should be mapped (enter, shift-enter, custom?) (enter as submit, shift+enter for newline)
       Choosing shift enter for new line and enter as submit for now.
- [x] Fix undo/redo (why doesn't it work?) (undo redo with partially modifiable buffer is complicated. I guess that's why it's disabled. What to do. a ton of edge cases. Particularly since under works in branches. Also buftype can be changed at any point) (undo/redo works up to last submit)
- [x] dd on prompt line clears the prompt too (fix it) (Entering insert mode again adds back the prompt. cc works by default)
- [x] o/O in normal mode doesn't work. it shoudl create a newline
       - check nv_open in normal.c, open_line in change.c . basic editibility check won't be enough. Probably the undo redo and dd ar the same. One key issue is operators can work on multiple lines at a time. How to handle that when only part of buffer is editable. For example with O on prompt line should we all text below it one line down and put a line there at prompt?
- [x] O at prompt location moves cursor to different line. figure out why. broken after switching to position tracking with mark for some reason. (fixed) (Although this blocks all mark updates during O operation at prompt line. Should be more granular? Is there a better way to do it other than adding a global flag?)
- [x] a/i at prompt location creates a new prompt in a newline when user input to prompt is none (fixed)
- [x] enter on normal mode submits the text should we retain this behavior? (Since we are keeping Enter as submit in insert too so keeping it as is makes sense)
- [x] When buftype is set to prompt set the last submit location to end of buffer (done)
- [x] Things like d5k doesn't work (it deletes non editable region) (broken on master too) (upon insert adds the prompt line. Was trying to block the edit. But got lost in `do_peding_operator()` . I've Tried adjusting the operator range. But doesn't seem to have effect. any suggestions?
- [x] Backspace doesn't work sometimes in prompt buffer where it should (Can't seem to reproduce now, most likely fixed with other backspace issues)

closes #32420
closes #32661

comment_data.body: can use memcpy since we already calculated the lengths. not sure why `concat_str` doesn't do that.

since `join_str` isn't joining a list (`ga_concat_strings_sep` does that already), it's probably not that useful. the normal way to do this would be like:

    a2 = concat_str(a, ",")
    a3 = concat_str(a2, b)

> (ga_concat_strings_sep does that already),

Great. I was so sure there has to be equivalent of this already in the codebase. But couldn't find it. I'll move it to reuse ga_concat_strings_sep. Or the above double call as you've suggested. I was trying to reduce the number of copies we make I think.

@justinmk this basically breaks current prompt buffer behavior. Since currently pressing `<enter>` directly submites the prompt. I don't think we should break this behavior. I can think of couple of alternatives

1. Make <enter> submit the user input and shift+<enter> enters a new line in prompt buffer. With it we have a question. Multiline paste needs to work with this too, obviously. But it won't directly work as it does like this. Since the paste won't have shift+enter. Is pasting tracked somewhere? Is there a way to differentiate paste from userinput? particularly when done with `<C-r>` in input mode?
2. Add a way to configure the submit button. set_prompt_submit_key("<cr>") for example. The default being `<cr>` when `<cr>` is used is submit key prompt buffer retains all current behavior with all it's flaws. If the submit key is set to some other key, then the multi line functionalities work.
3. Define e separate buftype for a multiline prompt buffer. separating it from the current prompt buffer behavior we have.

2 and 3 basically make multi-line support opt-in. I guess some combination of these can also be done. What do you think?

>  Is pasting tracked somewhere? Is there a way to differentiate paste from userinput? particularly when done with `<C-r>` in input mode?

yes, in `src/nvim/getchar.c`, see `paste_store` and `paste_repeat`. but, I think we shouldn't mess with that. 

instead, to avoid "breaking" the current prompt-buffer behavior, we can define a *default mapping* so that `<Enter>` continues to work as users expect. but plugins/users can easily support Enter-as-newline by *unmapping* that default mapping.

thus, internally, at a low-level, we use something like you have here to "submit". and we just define a default mapping for Enter (`:nnoremap <CR> <S-CR>`) in prompt-buffers.

> Add a way to configure the submit button. set_prompt_submit_key("") for example

can't that be a mapping (see above)? 

> Define e separate buftype for a multiline prompt buffer.

don't think we need this.

comment_regular_data.body:
> Track how much text has been submitted already to the prompt buffer callback.

here be dragons. does it handle deleted text? `dd` deletes text in prompt buffers.

is there a way we can avoid maintaining this extra state? tends to be fragile.

> here be dragons. does it handle deleted text? dd deletes text in prompt buffers.

It does handle text deletion in current prompt. And previous text before that is basically readonly. I think I did show c/d operations in the demo.

What I'm not sure if it handles right is probably editing actions through API. I haven't done serious testing on that but I suspect there might be bunch of edge-cases there.

> is there a way we can avoid maintaining this extra state? tends to be fragile.

True. I've been thinking about it. Before this the prompt was always lastline of buffer. When we allow multilines that's no longer true. It seems to me we have to track that state of it to work. Open to ideas though.

Also it's currently not worth reviewing. I had marely put together a quick prototype. It needs more work before it can be considered.

> It seems to me we have to track that state of it to work.

The `'[` / `']` marks are doing that to some extent. Ideally we can just re-use those, and any cases that are missed, can be delegated to that instead of managing it specifically for prompt buffers.

> > It seems to me we have to track that state of it to work.
> 
> The `'[` / `']` are doing that to some extent. Ideally we can just re-use those, and any cases that are missed, can be delegated to that instead of managing it specifically for prompt buffers.

I'm currently not aware of what they do. Will  look into that. If there's already something keeping track of things like that, it's definitely better to use that instead of adding a new one.

@justinmk I'm seeing that lots of the editing stuff doesn't support the prompt buffer. For example, undo/redo is disabled. Things like range edits (like `d5k` in normal mode) can modify read-only portions of the buffer. The main issue is the read-only and writeable segments in the same buffer. Good part of neovim treats it as non-existent. Or broadly disables the feature to avoid facing it. Can you check the Notes section in the pr? And provide your opinion on those? I feel like achieving 100% regular buffer like editing experience will be complicated. But we can probably get to 90% of that without way there. I'm not sure how to deal with undo/redo yet, though.

Also, I looked at '[ , '] marks. They basically kind of do the same. They work by adding Pos_T variables (b_op_start,, b_op_end) to the file_buffer struct, like I'm adding the line number here. Then the mark system uses those values from the buffer to expose those positions as marks. Even if we go that route, we'll be adding an additional state. With marks, we can expose it to the user, but that takes away at least a key for the mark spot. I'm not sure if any special ones are still unused. Also, we can't directly overload '[/ '] marks. They kind of represent completely different thing from what we are trying to achieve here.

> I feel like achieving 100% regular buffer like editing experience will be complicated. But we can probably get to 90% of that without way there. I'm not sure how to deal with undo/redo yet, though.

yeah, I don't think 100% is a goal. the idea of https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/32420 is primarily that the *input* (writable) section can intuitively support multiline input.

let's consider undo/redo out of scope, they aren't useful in prompt buffers afaik.

however, a major goal is that it should be easy for plugins to get the text of the *current prompt* (multiline or not) and be able to *update* the unsubmitted prompt. that avoids the need to support every editing feature, because then plugins can do fancy stuff in e.g. a floating window.

> How to handle buffer changes through API ?

plugins are free to do arbirary things to prompt-buffers. there is no defined expectation for this.

the important thing is that we maintain a meaningful region for the "writeable" (prompt) region vs the "readonly" region.

> The callback may insert or remove text in the buffer before we lock in the submit location?

the `'[` or `'.` mark tells us the last-changed part. we shouldn't be trying to calculate that any other way. if that mark is telling us the wrong thing, we need to find out why and perhaps fix it.

> however, a major goal is that it should be easy for plugins to get the text of the current prompt (multiline or not) and be able to update the unsubmitted prompt

That much is already done. 

> the important thing is that we maintain a meaningful region for the "writeable" (prompt) region vs the "readonly" region.

My question basically was, do we block changes in the readonly section from the API too? Or should we allow api to make arbitrary changes to the buffer? Even on the ReadOnly section. That gives extra power to the plugins. Technically, we can't exactly block it either. As the plugin can just switch the buftype to regular text make arbitrary changes, then switch back to the prompt buffer. So maybe it's not worth blocking APIs.

> the '[ or '. mark tells us the last-changed part. we shouldn't be trying to calculate that any other way. if that mark is telling us the wrong thing, we need to find out why and perhaps fix it.

That's different. It's doing what it's supposed to do. For example, say you are editing something in insert mode. Then went to different line edited that. The marks are keeping track of that. But that's not what we need we need the start of current prompt. Modifying the prompt is not one edit actions. There can be multiple as user switches between modes or applies some operator. The '[ mark will track only the last edit action not the whole prompt edit.

> The callback may insert or remove text in the buffer before we lock in the submit location?

That question is resolved now. We track the last submit location after callback is done. So any modifications done in the callback would be tracked. What we are not tracking is edits through api. I think I should take a look at mark/extmark subsystem to see if we can leverage that to keep track of api edits.

> let's consider undo/redo out of scope, they aren't useful in prompt buffers afaik.

An alternative would be to allow undo but delete the past undo history at submission (or perhaps rather reply) time. This makes it possible to undo while editing one specific input section, but you cannot undo things owned by the plugin or somehow go back to earlier sections.

> My question basically was, do we block changes in the readonly section from the API too?

Plugins (e.g. AI chat plugins) need to be able to show arbitrary stuff in the "readonly" section.

Why would we want to block changes to the readonly section? Our central task is to correctly set the "prompt" region, and we don't care what happens in the "readonly" region as long as the user *editing* UX isn't weird.

Using a extmark `nvim_buf_set_extmark()` may "track" changes, or at least it should in theory. Try setting an extmark on the readonly "boundary", and it should adjust as edits are made (by plugin code) to the "readonly" region.

> An alternative would be to allow undo but delete the past undo history at submission (or perhaps rather reply) time. This makes it possible to undo while editing one specific input section, but you cannot undo things owned by the plugin or somehow go back to earlier sections.

That's a really good idea. I'll try that out.

> Plugins (e.g. AI chat plugins) need to be able to show arbitrary stuff in the "readonly" section.
Why would we want to block changes to the readonly section? Our central task is to correctly set the "prompt" region, and we don't care what happens in the "readonly" region as long as the user editing UX isn't weird.

Yeah we don't want to block that. That basic chat behavior is already possible by modifying the buffer in submission callback. What's missing is is if some arbitary edit is done on read only part outside of the callback. Because that can break how last prompt submit is tracked. 

For example, currently master. Prompt buffer submits last line all the time. Say user is modifying editing the prompt submission. At that moment some other running code appends to the buffer. Basically changing the location of last line. Now users old input is practically lost. Last line would get submitted to callback at enter. We are still suffering from that issue in the pr too. But in a different way. If some line get's added/removed in the readonly section (text above current prompt)  we will sent wrong lines in submission as our last submit position is wrong. This issue doesn't occur if edits are done in prompt submit callback as we expect changes to happen in that windows.

So basically even if we aren't blocking the ali edits in readonly we want to keep track of them. I'll checkout how extmarks track edits. I think having last submit location as extmark would be much more useful then just a LineNo.

Can Neovim detect Shift+Enter on all kinds of terminals? Or at least on most of them? I primarily use kitty. But also tried out on konsole (kde terminal) there it doesn't seem to detect shifted `<CR>`.

Now I feel like assigning `<CR>` for submit and `<S-CR>` as insert line is better. Because,
1. Keeps backward compatibility. `<CR>` just submits as before
2. `<S-CR>` is always available for entering multiple lines on all prompt buffers. Plugins don't need to add explicit support.
    if they don't want multiline text they can just map `<S-CR>` to `<NOP>`  `inoremap <S-CR> <NOP>`. It's also pretty simple to just split the input before processing in the callback
3. If in some terminal, neovim can't detect `<S-CR>` prompt buffer still works. Although multiline won't work. At least, single-line inputs will be working. Technically, multiline can still be done with `o/O` in normal mode even in that case. On the other hand, if we map `<CR>` to `<S-CR>` and treat that as submit prompt buffers will be completely broken. As submitting won't work without `<S-CR>` being detected.
4. If some plugin want's `<CR>` to add newline and `<S-CR>` to be submit. They can just remap the keys.
```viml
     inoremap <CR> <S-CR>
     inoremap <S-CR> <CR>
```

Particularly, 2 and 3 are clear wins compared to the other approach, and we don't lose anything doing it this way.

> Can Neovim detect Shift+Enter on all kinds of terminals? Or at least on most of them? I primarily use kitty. But also tried out on konsole (kde terminal) there it doesn't seem to detect shifted `<CR>`.

This really doesn't matter because we are only establishing a builtin keycode (`<s-enter>`). We can always define a (additional) default mapping or whatever if needed. 

The reason that I suggested redefining the internal "submit" action to `<s-enter>` is so that we can avoid special handling of input that contains newlines.

We can define default mappings that keep the old familiar interface,

     inoremap <CR> <S-CR>

 but it seems convenient and simpler for the builtin keycode to be `<s-enter>`.

> We can define default mappings that keep the old familiar interface,
```
 inoremap <CR> <S-CR>
````
> but it seems convenient and simpler for the builtin keycode to be `<s-enter>`.

I think my point for consistency still stands. If we map `<CR>` to `<S-CR>` user/plugin will have to explicitly unmap this plugin to use multiline input and paste. Also even if we do that unless we also block out things like o/O too multiline input can still be made. And since the mapping can be unmapped from user side too so it's not exactly gurateed for plugins either that multiline input won't be there by default.
If we map use `<S-CR>` as new line after merge all prompt buffers from now on will have support for multiline input in same manner by default. Plugin/users don't need to change anything they just get a new feature from core.
Basically if we keep multiline disabled by default it most of users/plugins won't enable it. Even if some do it'll just be inconsistant in users eye as in some prompts multiline would work and in some it won't. On the other hand if we keep it enabled by default most of the users/plugins will keep them enabled leading to more consistant multiline  experience.

For example I had written a [IRC client](https://github.com/shadmansaleh/irc.nvim) for neovim long long ago. The chat was basically implemented with prompt buffers. There's basically nothing need to change there with `<S-CR>` being newline. It's just a new feature in core that improves the plugin too. In this case that plugin is basically unmaintained. What I'm trying to say is if we keep it enabled by default even older plugins not following master will have the feature : ] 

> The reason that I suggested redefining the internal "submit" action to <s-enter> is so that we can avoid special handling of input that contains newlines.

It only matters for `<C-r>` in insert mode. If we go with the `<C-r>` rework you proposed yesterday that also becomes irrelevant

 > This really doesn't matter because we are only establishing a builtin keycode (`<s-enter>`). We can always define a (additional) default mapping or whatever if needed.

Yeah that extra mapping can be done on higher layer. We won't have to touch the c codes. I was mainly asking it to see if we need a better default. From the terminals I've tried kitty and wezterm can detect `<S-CR>` I've heard iterm supports it too (haven't tested). Alacrity can't detect it there's an open issue on their repo...

> It only matters for `<C-r>` in insert mode. If we go with the `<C-r>` rework you proposed yesterday that also becomes irrelevant

It becomes less urgent, but is still relevant for `<c-r>=@x` and probably some other situations.

Not a blocker for now, we can see if it matters in practice.

After the few minor comments above, this is probably ready to merge imo, though I might take a closer look at the tests later.

> Should we expose this location to user somehow?

We definitely want some way for plugins to easily ask "what is the current prompt text" without mucking around with getline(), marks, etc. Is that part of this PR?, if not can be a followup.

I've fixed the concerns you had in review.

> Not a blocker for now, we can see if it matters in practice.

Great. Then we can keep it like this for now. We can see it in the master. Until 0.12 gets released, the behavior isn't fixed either way.

> After the few minor comments above, this is probably ready to merge imo, though I might take a closer look at the tests later.

Do take a look as you get time, and let me know if any change is needed or if you need any clarification. Also, do I need to get commitlint to pass? Doing squash merge should be enough, right?  If you want I can do a rebase and squash all the commits. for now I haven't squashed them, so you can easily check the changes made after your review.

> We definitely want some way for plugins to easily ask "what is the current prompt text" without mucking around with getline(), marks, etc. Is that part of this PR?, if not can be a followup.

It's not there for now. Currently plugins can only get the prompt text when user submits. Though adding an api for that is not complex ( we just need to agree on a api signature/name :] ) . I can do it in a followup..

> Also, do I need to get commitlint to pass?

no i'll squash

> just need to agree on a api signature/name :] ) . I can do it in a followup..

is this tracked in todo list / issue somewhere ?

> is this tracked in todo list / issue somewhere ?

I've added it to my gsoc tracking discussion. And pr open at #34491. Will finalize it after this gets merged.
